PFT was done earlier—his FEV1 was 70%, which improved to 83% after bronchodilator nebulization. He was already on MDI Albuterol daily. On questioning, it seems like he is being symptomatic for at least 2 times per week and is waking up in the nights due to symptoms at least once per week. On examination, there are scattered rhonchi. What should be done? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Add Fluticasone MDI two times a day

 

The patient’s symptoms indicate that his asthma is not well-controlled with short-acting beta-agonist (Albuterol) alone. Inhaled corticosteroids (ICS), such as Fluticasone, are essential in asthma management because they address airway inflammation, which is a key component of asthma pathophysiology. Adding an ICS will help reduce symptoms, improve lung function, and prevent exacerbations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Shift to MDI Salmeterol two times a day: Salmeterol is a long-acting beta-agonist (LABA) that can help control symptoms but does not address the underlying inflammation. LABA should not be used as monotherapy in asthma without an accompanying ICS due to the risk of worsening asthma control.

 

Option C. Add Prednisolone 10mg: Prednisolone is a systemic corticosteroid, which is generally reserved for severe asthma exacerbations or patients who do not respond to standard therapy (steps 5 and 6 of the asthma management algorithm). Long-term use is associated with significant side effects, making it inappropriate for this patient’s current condition.

 

Option D. Continue the current management: Continuing the current management is not appropriate as the patient is symptomatic, indicating inadequate asthma control. Adjusting the treatment plan is necessary to improve his symptoms and prevent nighttime awakenings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhaled corticosteroids are the cornerstone of asthma management as they effectively reduce airway inflammation, improve symptoms, and prevent exacerbations. They should be added when asthma symptoms are not controlled by a short-acting beta-agonist alone.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of this patient from the ECG shown below? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ventricular tachycardia

 

The ECG displays a rhythm with broad QRS complexes at a high rate, consistent with ventricular tachycardia (VT). VT is characterized by three or more consecutive ventricular beats at a rate of more than 100 beats per minute. The presence of such a pattern, particularly with a stable, repetitive form as seen in the ECG, strongly points to VT rather than other types of arrhythmias.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal ECG: This option is incorrect as the ECG clearly shows an abnormal rhythm with broad QRS complexes, indicative of an arrhythmia originating below the AV node.

 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Ventricular fibrillation is characterized by irregular, chaotic electrical activity without identifiable QRS complexes, P waves, or T waves. The rhythm shown here is too organized and regular to be VF.

 

Option D. Misplaced leads: Misplaced leads causes positive p in aVR with normal intervals - R wave progression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular tachycardia is identified by regular, broad QRS complexes at a rapid rate, distinct from the irregular pattern of ventricular fibrillation and the organized, narrower complexes typically seen with supraventricular rhythms and correct lead placement. Identifying VT on an ECG is critical due to its potential severity and the need for prompt treatment.

questions.text: A child presented with the following deformity. Labs show the following: Serum calcium - Normal, PTH - Normal, Phosphate - Low, ALP - Raised. What is the probable defect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypophosphatemic rickets

 

Hypophosphatemic rickets is characterized by low serum phosphate levels, normal calcium, normal PTH, and elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP). This type of rickets is not due to vitamin D deficiency but rather a phosphate metabolism disorder, often related to renal phosphate wasting. In hypophosphatemic rickets, PTH and calcium levels are typically normal, which helps differentiate it from other forms of rickets.

 

The normal calcium and PTH levels are the main clues in this case, as they help distinguish hypophosphatemic rickets from other conditions such as vitamin D dependent rickets types 1 and 2, where calcium would be low, and PTH would typically be elevated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin D dependent rickets 1: This condition is due to a deficiency in 1-alpha hydroxylase, which impairs the activation of vitamin D. Patients typically present with low calcium and elevated PTH, which does not match the lab results shown here.

 

Option C. Vitamin D dependent rickets 2: This condition involves resistance to vitamin D due to a defect in the vitamin D receptor. Similar to type 1, calcium levels would be low, and PTH would be elevated, not matching this patient’s profile.

 

Option D. Nutritional Rickets: This condition is primarily due to vitamin D deficiency and would usually present with low calcium and elevated PTH, making it unlikely in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypophosphatemic rickets presents with normal calcium, normal PTH, low phosphate, and elevated ALP, distinguishing it from other rickets types where calcium and PTH abnormalities are typically present.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of aprepitant? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NK1 antagonist


Aprepitant is a Neurokinin 1 (NK1) receptor antagonist that works by blocking the action of substance P, a neuropeptide associated with the emesis reflex. It is primarily used to prevent chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV), especially in patients receiving highly emetogenic chemotherapy agents like cisplatin. By inhibiting NK1 receptors in the brain, aprepitant effectively reduces the incidence of nausea and vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:


Aprepitant is an NK1 receptor antagonist used in preventing chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting by blocking the action of substance P.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with weight loss, heat intolerance, and palpitations over the past two months. Laboratory tests reveal decreased TSH and elevated T3 and T4 levels. She is started on iodine-131 therapy. What is the most common long-term side effect of this treatment? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypothyroidism

 

Explanation:

 

I-131 (radioactive iodine) therapy is commonly used for hyperthyroidism (Graves' disease). The most common long-term side effect is hypothyroidism, due to:

 

  • Destruction of thyroid tissue
  • Permanent reduction in thyroid hormone production

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism relapse: Rare, as radioactive iodine typically leads to permanent thyroid destruction

 

Option B. Thyroid storm: Acute complication, not a long-term effect

 

Option D. Radiation-induced thyroiditis: Can occur but is a transient complication

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothyroidism is the most common long-term side effect of radioactive iodine (I-131) therapy, requiring lifelong thyroid hormone replacement.

questions.text: A patient with a history of smoking presents with a cough and hemoptysis. A chest X-ray is done and it is shown below. Which of the following findings is least likely to be associated with this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Exophthalmos

 

Explanation:

 

The X-ray findings suggest a Pancoast tumor (superior sulcus tumor), which can invade adjacent structures, causing:

 

  • Brachial plexopathy (compression of lower brachial plexus)
  • Horner’s syndrome (ptosis, miosis, anhidrosis) due to sympathetic chain involvement
  • Superior vena cava syndrome due to compression of the superior vena cava

 

Exophthalmos is more commonly associated with Graves’ disease and is not a feature of Pancoast tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horner syndrome: Incorrect because this is a common finding in Pancoast tumor due to involvement of the sympathetic chain

 

Option B. Brachial plexopathy: Incorrect because this is commonly seen due to compression of the lower part of the brachial plexus by the tumor

 

Option C. Superior vena cava syndrome: Incorrect because SVC syndrome can occur in Pancoast tumors due to compression or invasion of the superior vena cava

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pancoast tumors present with Horner’s syndrome, brachial plexopathy, and superior vena cava syndrome, but exophthalmos is not part of the presentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient diagnosed with chronic hepatitis B infection is being evaluated for infectivity status. Which of the following markers indicates high infectivity? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HBeAg

 

Explanation:

 

HBeAg (Hepatitis B e antigen) is a marker of viral replication and infectivity in chronic hepatitis B infection. Its presence indicates:

 

  • High levels of viral replication
  • Higher risk of transmission
  • Greater infectivity
  • Usually associated with higher HBV DNA levels
  • Important prognostic marker for complications like cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-HBc: Indicates current or past HBV infection, but not infectivity

 

Option B. Anti-HBs: Indicates immunity (through vaccination or recovery), not infectivity

 

Option D. HBsAg: Indicates infection, but does not differentiate between high and low infectivity

 

Educational Objective:

 

HBeAg is a key marker of high viral replication and infectivity in chronic hepatitis B infection.
